document.text: WILEY H. ROBERTSON Funeral services for Wiley Hogue Robertson, 87, were con ducted at 2 p.m. Sunday at Ro binson Funeral Home with bur ial in the Old Concord Presby terian Church Cemetery. A retired postmaster and mer chant, he died at 330 a.m. F ri day in his home at Spout Spring. He was the husband of thelate Rosa Bondurant Robertson. Born in Appomattox County, he was the son of Calvin Ro bertson and EllaShear eiRobert- son. He was the father of the late Appomattox County Sheriff David T. Robertson. He was an elder of Old Concord Presby terian Church. He is survived by two sons, Shearer B. Robertson of Spout Spring and W. Howard Robert son of Altavista three daugh ters, Mrs. Theodore Carson of Altavista, Mrs. Joe H. Asher of Brookneal and Mrs. Burt Broom of Atlanta, Ga. one brother, J. O. Robertson of Spout Spring, nine grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: The pace has stepped up in acti vity among candidates for office as the August 7 primary election date approaches. Appomattox voters will decide on contests in two districts for supervisor, and a contest for county sheriff. In Southside District, F. L. Murphy, incumbent, is being opposed by C. C. Harvey. In Clover Hill District, F. A. OBrien, incum bent, is opposed by Harry A. Will iams, of Pamplin. For sheriff, David T. Robertson, incumbent, is oppos ed by Vernell Mitchell.

document.text: SPOUT SPRING  Mrs. Rosa Bondurant Robertson, 78, died Monday night in Lynchburg Gen eral Hospital. She was born in j Nelson County, the daughter of David Thomas and Willie Em- I ma Carter Bondurant. She was a member of the Old Concord Presbyterian Church at Spout Spring. Survivors include her husband, Wiley Hogue Robertson two sons. Shearer B. Robertson, of Spout Spring and W. Howard Ro bertson, of Altavista three daughters, Mrs. Theodore Car- son, of Altavista, Mrs. Joe H. Asher, of Brookneal and Mrs. Bert Broom, of Pompano Beach, Fla. two brothers, Wallace Bon durant and T. J. Bondurant, both of Concord one sister, Mrs. Ida Stratton, of Concord nine grand children and two great - grand children. She also was the mother of the late Sheriff David T. Robertson of Appomattox County. Funeral services were held at 3 p.m. Wednesday at Robinson Funeral Home in Appomattox. Burial was in the Old Concord Presbyterian Church Cemetery.

document.text: Sheriff David T. Robertson an nounced this week that he has ap pointed two part time deputies to assist in extra police duties in the county. They are Walter Phelps, at Oakville, who will act as jail guard in the absence of the jailer, and Thomas G. Catlett at Pamplin, who will serve papers, both criminal and civil, and other general law enforce ment work in the jPamplin area. .Mrs. Walter Phelps was also ap pointed Justice of the Peace, for Stonewall District, and will act as Justice of the Peace in the absence of Mrs. Walter Conner from the jail and Mrs. Vaida L. Catlett, wife of the new Pamplin deputy, will be Jus tice of the Peace for the Pamplin area, Clover Hill District. Sheriff Robertson states that Mr. and Mrs. Catlett were appointed es pecially to help the people of the Pamplin area and on request of the Town Council of Pamplin. The sheriff states that there will be no allowance for any salary for these appointees from the county treasurer, but the Justices will be paid on. a fee basis at no cost to the county, and the new deputies will receive pay according to what they do and the cases they work on, such to be approved by the sheriff and the county board of supervisors at the end of each month and the state will pay two-thirds of this amount. The fees collected by the new deputies and paid into the county treasury will offset the balance of the one- third to be paid by the county.

document.text: OLD CANNON NEVER DIE  Old cannot never die, you just re mount them on a new carriage. For many years, since the time of the late Congressman Hal Flood, two- Civil War cannon have been display ed in the courtyard here. They ac tually were Federal and not Con federate in their history. Months ago Sheriff David T. Robertson noted the deteriorated condition of the carriages, and suggested to the coun ty board of supervisors that the car riages be rebuilt. The work was done in Pamplin, and has now been com pleted. So this item on the court house should be good for a new lease on life.

document.text: Nearly 800 ballots were cast in Appomattox Countys ten precincts in Tuesdays General Election, as all Democratic nominees were elect ed without opposition. The vote wa3 considered a fairly good showing in the light of lack of opposing candi dates and was slightly ahead of the total vote in last years general elec tion. J. H. OBrien, commissioner of the revenue, topped the voting with a total of 73 b ballots, closely follow ed by J. Garland Plunkett with 736 for county treasurer. The big court house,precinct here- was just short of 300 votes cast. State Senator Chas. T. Moses was re-elected to another four-year term, receiving 718 ballots in the county. Delegate John B. Boatwright receiv ed 665. Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt Jr. received 692 votes, sheriff David T. Robertson 693,and the 3 unopposed candidates for supervisor, F. L. Murphy, Otho Matrin Jr. and R. M. Webb received 320, 213, and 186 votes respectively. Interest over the state centered in a few contests for the State Senate and House of Delegates, where Re publican or Independent carididates sought to win over Democrats. In most cases the Democrats won, al though Ted Dalton was returned to the State Senate and gained pres tige for another possible bid for the Governorship.

document.text: Appomattox County Sheriff David T. Robertson gets his man even if he gets bitn in doing so. This week he was bitten in the stomach by a prisoner he was escorting  to jail. Trooper Bob Smith was driving the officers car and Sheriff Robert son had the prisoner on the back seat seeking to control the prison ers tendency to resist arrest. Then the prisoner bit the sheriff through his clothing, causing a wound which required three stitches.

document.text: A campaign to alert the public to the dangers of blasting caps was launched today by Sheriff David T. Robertson. A child finding a blast ing cap must let it alone, the offi cer said, as he would a rattle snake. Know a cap when you see one, to avoid deadly danger, is the sheriffs advice. Blasting caps are bright copper or aluminum tubes, about as big around as a pencil, and from an inch and a half to five inches long. A cap may or may not have a fuse attached. Some have plain or colored wires at one end. They contain a highly sensitive explos ive and are necessary to explode dynamite to build bridges, roads and skyscrapers, quarry stoned mines, and especially pipe line pro- jects. Sheriff Robertson explained that some youngsters recognize the caps when they see them, but do not understand their real danger. They seem to instinctively know, he said that caps will explode and make a noise and so hit them deliberately with a rock or hammer. Some times they throw them into fires just to hear the expolsion. Last year as a result of such accidents, many chil dren were seriously injured. Some lost fingers of hands, othere were blinded for life. The sheriff explained that he is

document.text: A full-scale national defense alert will be staged tomorrow, Fri day, with the nation getting a taste of what will have to be done in event of enemy attack. Appomattox County Civil De fense Director David T. Robertson, County Sheriff, states that the alert signal will be sounded here on the fire siren at 1008 A. M. That will be in the form of a steady blast of from 3 to 5 minutes. The take cover signal goes on at 1245 P. M., and will be in the form of wailing blasts of short du ration. The set-up plans for a simulated attack on 76 critical centers in the nation at 115 P. M. The all clear of the actual simulated at tack will come at 200 P. M. Radio Conelrad will be put into effect at 310 P. M. to 345 P. M. During that interim all radio stations will be silent and defense announcements will be carried only at 64 or 1240 on radio dials. document.text: The effects of the stepped up de fense program advocated by Presi- dnt Kennedy this week, may soon be felt in all area of the nation. A first probability is an inersass in draft calls by the Selective Service. For some time, thé calls for this county have been only one dr .. tee per monjtih. Re enlistments of those already in the armed serv ices have kept at a normal level the number of men from this county in the various services. t It is now likely, it is believed, the draft calls will be at least doubled. The county has a fairly long list of men in the available group. The calls for those who take armed force physical examinations may be increased. .. As a further possible development the Civil Defense Progjram is likely b be stepped up, John Cole is the Civil .Defense chairman for Appomattox County, haring succeeded the late Sheriff Kv . .. 4 . - - David T. Robertson. Chas. F. V. Orawwley is co-ordinator, Mr. Colo advised yesterday that several new committees will be set-up. County Treasurer J. Garland Plunkett and Thomas T. Martin ape the announced candidates. David T. Robertson, the incum bent sheriff, was appointed to fill out the term of the late H. W. Mc Kinney, and four years ago won a full term. He was opposed in that election four years ago by Vernell Mitchell. Sheriff Robertson inform ed The Times-Virginian this week that he would be a candidate, and to date no other has announced. The two-way race for Commission er of the Revenue will find H. H. Caldwell, Jr. opposing the veteran incumbent, J. H. OBrien. Mr. Cald- will be making his first bid for public office. He is the son of H. H. Caldwell, of Route 3, Appomattox. He graduated at Appomattox High School in 1943 and entered the Navy as Aviation Cadet August 10 of that year. While in the service he took special courses at the Universities of South Carolina and Georgia. He served on the USS. Bismarck Sea, and was on same when the carrier was sunk by a Jap dive bomber at tack Feb. 23, 1945. He was among the rescued survivors. He entered V. P. I. in the fall of 1945, and re ceived his B. S. degree in 1949. He was president of the civilian student foody his senior year. Since he has been employed with American To bacco Co., Schaffer Pen Co., and since 1954 with Gary Steel Products Corp, Lynchburg, as assistant to the general sales manager..

document.text: There are four contests awaiting the decision of the voters. In Stonewall Magisterial District there is a three-way race for the office of supervisor. Incumbent John P. Alvis, Jr., is being opposed by O. W. Martin, Jr., and Hpbert B. Scruggs. Over 800 votes are expect ed at the three precincts in Stone wall District. Veteran incumbent James H. OBrien is being opposed for nomi nation for another-term as Commis sioner of the Revenue by H. H. Caldwell, Jr. - Incumbent David T. Robertson is being opposed for Sheriff by J. Alex Bingham, a retired State Police Lieutenant. Deputy Treasurer John Garland Plunkett and Thomas Terrill Martin, are vieing for the nomination for County Treasurer. These contests have been the oc casion of active campaigns, both by the contestants and their friends. Many letters have been mailed to the voters and personal appeals have kept all hands on the go fonthe past three months. Predictions as to the outcome de pend on which side you question, but the overa-all conclusion is that there will be a heavy vote and that at least some of the contests will be close. Most contestants are preparing their workers for a major effort on1! election day and will try to see that no eligible voter fails to go to the polls. There are ten voting precincts in Appomattox County. Election offi cials, aeording to a list secured by this newspaper yesterday, will be as follows Court House Precinct Judges J. H. Lucado, L J. Mor ris and J. W. Durrum. Clerks Mrs. L. L. Stanley and Mrs. Lou C. Rog ers.

document.text: CIRCUIT COURT Appomattox-Circuit Court session today for the June David T. Robertson has been ap pointed as sheriff of Appomattox County to serve out the unexpired term of the late H. W. McKinney. The new sheriff has been a deputy sher for several years, is a World War II veteran and has been active in local civic affairs for some years.

document.text: Appomattox voters were given another contest today, as J. Alex Bingham announced as a candidate for county sheriff. He will oppose the incumbent, David T. Robertson, in the Democratic Primary Election of July 12. Contests have already been an nounced for county treasurer, com missioner of the revenue, and super visor in the Stonewall District. Mr. Bingham is a retired Lieute nant, Virginia State Police. He be gan police work in 1922 as an in spector. He was promoted to lieute nant in 1930 and assigned to the Central Virginia territory. In 1942 he became a Special Investigator of the Virginia Department of State Police. It had been reported here for sev eral weeks that Mr. Bingham plan ned on seeking the office of sheriff, but he made formal announcement to the Times-Virginian this week. His opponent, Mr. Robertson, was appointed by the court to serve out the term of the late H. W. McKin ney, and then four years ago won election for a full term. Both of these contestants are popular and experienced police offi cers. Abbitt Announces Commonwealth Attorney George F. Abbitt, Jr. informed the Times- Virginian this week that he would be a candidate for re-election. It is considered certain that he will not have opposition. Candidates for commissioner of revenue are the incumbent, J, H. OBrien, and H. H. Caldwell, Jr. Candidates for county treasurer are deputy treasurer J. Garland Plunkett, and Thomas Terrill Mar tin, local businessman. Contestants for supervisor in the Stonewall District are H. H. Scruggs and O. W. Martin, Jr. NOTICE . .  c  w All children who will begin school at Oakville, Vera and Spout Spring schools this fall, and have not bad their examination, please come to the Appomattox Health Center on Thursday, April 7, 1955, between 900 A. M. and 230 P. M. All other children who have not had their preschool examination please also come on this day, as this is the last day for these exami nations. ,

document.text: A record 2,603 votes wire cast in Appomattox County Tuesday, as voters of the county chose a Dem ocratic nominee for County Treas- arer Sheriff, and Cimmissioner of the Revenue, and Stonewall District chose a Supervisor.. According to Times - Virginian files, this was the largest vote ever cast in the county. It compared with 2,133 in February, 1948 in a social congressional election, and 1,989 in the 1952 presidential election. James H. OBrien lead the ticket in the county, defeating H. H. Cald well, Jr. for Commissioner of the Revenue, 1,722 t 847. OBrien car ried every precinct but Chap. David T. Robertson won over J. Alex Bingham for Sheriff, by a vote of 1,466 to 1,114. Bingham carried Rocks and Agee precincts. J. Garland Plunkett, incumbent deputy Treasurer defeated Thomas Terrell Martin for the nominatiin for Treasurer, in the countys clos est race. The unofficial tabulation gave Plunkett a 200 vote margin in a spirited race. Plunkett piled up a lead at the Court House and the Old Court House precincts. Martin carried Cheatwood, Chap, Walkers Church, Agee, Oakville and Stone wall precints, his biggest margin be ing at Oakville. There was a record 962 vote at the Court House precinct, and sev eral hundred citizens gathered to wait until nearly 11 P. M. for the cimpletion of the ballot count.  In the Stonewall District, . Otha W. Martin, Jr. handily defeated two opponents for Supervisor. He re ceived 396 votes, to 234 for John P. Alvis, Jr., incumbent, and HuT bert B. Scruggs received 92. Martin swept the Oakville and Agee precincts and Alvis carried the Stonewall precinct.

document.text: Appomattox Sheriff David T. Rob ertson early today stated that po lice were MweeWgaWng a robbery which occurred at AveraKt Depart ment Store here over the holiday. The Sheriff informed the Times- Virginian this morning that a sum listed as approximately 1,250 was taken from a safe in the store of fice sometime between dosing time Christmas Eve, and yesterday after noon when the theft was discover ed. State Police were cbOed in, and a check made fox finger-prints and other possible clues. The Sheriff stated that entrance to the store was gained through a door leading to the Masonic Hall, located on the second floor of the building. From that entrance, a door leading from a hall landing to the store was used. Sheriff Robertson later informed this paper that the exact sum miss ing was 1,269.48. He also stated that Trooper Reynold, of the State Police was assigned to join with him in an investigation.

document.text: - On a recent Sunday, it was our very great pleasure to visit the at tractive vacation cottage of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Robertson, on Buggs Island Lake. A friend of theirs took us on a long lake ride in his new cruiser, and then we motored up to Clarksville and saw the wonderful collection of Indian relics belonging to Judge John Tis dale, Meehlemburg County Judge. We have a modest few hundred Indian arrowheads, but Judge Tis dale has 20,000, believe it or not! He has a lodge which features an incredible array of Arrowheads and other Indian relies attached to the upper walls. Most of his collection came from the Buggs Island area. Father Darkelaf and Sheriff Rob ertson set up plans for an expedi tion of their own to seek arrow heads in that area, but so far the opportunity has not presented itself.

document.text: The dramatic . trial of Frank Mayberry, 47 year old railway weld ers helper, of Evergreen, accused in the shot-in-the-dark killing of Dr. David A. Christian, III, on the night of Feb. 25, came to an end here late Saturday night, when a jury summoned from Cumberland County brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree with punishment fixed at imprison ment In the state penitentiary for life, f Mayberry was taken to Richmond -Monday to begin his term. Decision has not been made by his attorneys, W. F. Watkins, Jr., and J. B. Wall, Jr., of Farmyille, as to an apepal of the conviction nor has a decision been announced by the Commonwealth as to prose cution of a second indictment, charging the murder of Mayberrys brother-in-law, Jack Tucker. The trial began Friday morning and ended as midnight approached Saturday. The court room was pack ed during most of the two days, pnd the case attracted wide publici ty. High-water mark of the trial came when Mayberry took the stand to testify, and in a calm, quiet man ner declared, I feel mighty bad about it. For myself, and for the doctors family, and my people. The Story of the Trial At 1005 A. M. Friday, the sheriff, D. T. Robertson, brought the defendant, Frank Mayberry, into court, before a crowded courtroom. Rob ertson after Robertson was kill ed in an auto accident in De cember 1960. Conner had been a deputy un der Robertson since 1950 A veteran of World War II, Conner served in the First Ar mored Division with 32 months overseas duty out of his four years, eight months in service. He attended Appomattox schools and is married to the former Miss Lucille Sheperla, of Lynch burg. The Conners have two chil dren, Neil and Donna Gail, both students at Appomattox H ig h School.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.
